affiliation: 2 David M. Robinson is Professor of Management and Marketing at Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge. He received his Ph.D. from the same university in 1961. While a Fulbright Professor in Finland in 1966–67 he completed work on a monograph Consumer Behavior in the American Marketplace which was published by Handelshögkolan vid Abo Akademi. title: Information and Rational Choice
affiliation: 3 Lawrence L. Schkade is Professor of Business Administration at North Texas State University. The author's recent research has been in the derivation of normative models of rational choice for individuals and the results have been published in a series of articles published in Annals of CPCU, Journal of Business, Journal of Risk and Insurance, and Revista de la Escuela de Contabilidad, and Economis y Administracion. title: A Job-Oriented Management Workshop

title: Content Analysis—a Probabilistic Approach
affiliation: 1 Mervin D. Lynch is an SSRC Fellow at Harvard University. He has held positions at the University of Missouri, and at Indiana University. title: Content Analysis—a Probabilistic Approach

title: Communication Research and the American Labor Union
affiliation: 1 Mark L. Knapp is an assistant professor in the Department of Communication, University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee and Research Fellow in the Speech Communication Center. title: Communication Research and the American Labor Union
affiliation: 2 James C. McCroskey is an assistant professor in the Department of Speech, College of Communication Arts, Michigan State University. title: Book Review Section
From the Editor
The Language of Dada
affiliation: 1 Manuel L. Grossman is Assistant Professor of Speech at Boston College. Previously, he taught at the State University of New York at Buffalo and at New York University. Mr. Grossman holds a B.A. from the University of Michigan, an M.A. from Brooklyn College, and a Ph.D. from New York University. Mr. Grossman's publications include “Propaganda Techniques in Selected Essays of George Bernard Shaw,”Southern Speech Journal, in the Spring of 1967 and “Alfred Jarry and the Theatre of the Absurd,” to be published by the Educational Theatre Journal. His doctoral dissertation, “A Study of Farcical Elements in the Theatre of Alfred Jarry,” has recently been revised and will be published by Syracuse University Press under the title The Theatre of Alfred Jarry. At the present time Mr. Grossman is writing a monograph of the Dada movement which will be part of a comparative literature series to be published by Pegasus Press

title: Responsivity to Facial and Linguistic Cues
affiliation: 1 Jeffrey G. Shapiro is presently a Senior Research Scientist at Arkansas Rehabilitation Research and Training Center, and Assistant Professor of Psychology at the University of Arkansas. He earned his doctorate in Clinical Psychology at the Pennsylvania State University in 1965, and took an internship at the Napa State Hospital, Imola, California. His major research interests are in the communication of affect and personality through nonlinguistic cues, and in the effect of discrepancy of cues on the individual judge. He is also presently studying the inherently helpful person, and the ability of the therapeutic personality to influence the productivity and comfort of those with whom he interacts

title: Communications in a Public Bureaucracy: Involvement and Performance
affiliation: 1 L. L. Wade (Ph.D., University of Oregon) is Assistant Professor of Political Science at Purdue University and a former staff member of the U.S. Bureau of the Budget. He has taught at the University of North Carolina (Charlotte) and San Fernando Valley State College and has published articles dealing with administrative perceptions and the behavior of organizational professionals. He is the coauthor of two forthcoming books, Primer of Political Analysis (with D. Strickland and R. Johnston) and A Theory of Political Exchange (with R. Curry). Current research interests include administrative recruitment, bargaining theory, and a projected study of the future of systematic political theory in which the problem of political communications willl provide an important focus

title: A Denotative and Connotative Study in Communication
affiliation: 1 Robert L. Minter is a lecturer in the Program in Speech Communication, at State University of New York, Buffalo, where he is establishing a graduate program in organizational/industrial communication. A Ph.D. candidate in organizational communication at Purdue University, he expects to receive his degree this spring. His AB. and M.A. degrees were received from Miami University of Ohio. His professional interests concern analyses of communication dysfunctions within organizational settings

title: Organizational Processes Underlying Differences between Listening and Reading as a Function of Complexity of Material
affiliation: 1 Milton W. Horowitz is an associate professor of psychology at Queens College of the City University of New York. He received his doctorate from Stanford University in 1947 and accepted his first position at the University of Kansas. Horowitz' early research was in small group processes and interpersonal relations. This interest led, inevitably, to studies of communication, psycholinguistics, and language and thought, in general. His present research interests include the use of the four modalities listening, reading, speaking, writing to understand coding, organizing, and ordering processes of the mind and the relationship of affective and signal material on the one hand, and cognitive material on the other, to these coding properties. Hopefully, the research will also discover additional reasons (related to the modalities above) why some material is readily available in memory and other material is available only with difficulty, or not at all

title: A Systematic Way of Being Creative
affiliation: 1 Robert R. Monaghan is an associate professor at Ohio State University. He is a former NBC network producer, now turned media researcher. He also worked as General Manager of the Oregon Association of Broadcasters, and taught broadcast journalism and station-network management in the School of Journalism at the University of Oregon for three years. He holds an M.A. in broadcasting and speech from Stanford University, and a Ph.D. in communication from Michigan State University. His current teaching and research interests lean toward analysis of the professional communicator and his audiences, research methods, and small group communication. title: The Dimensions of Source Credibility of Television Newscasters

title: Communication Needs of the Active Union Member

title: The Internet for the Blind and Visually Impaired

At Monash University, ITNR is within the Enterprise Information Research Group (EIRG). Kirsty Williamson is the Director of ITNR; Don Schauder is the Chair; Louise Stockfeld is Research Associate and Steve Wright is Research Fellow. Amanda Bow is a former Research Associate. The present article reflects the philosophy of ITNR which has a specifically ‘user’ focus in relation to information and telecommunications needs of community groups. In the last 2 years, ITNR has undertaken two major projects about online services for people with disabilities funded by the Australian Commonwealth Government. Another project, funded by the Australian Research Council, was specifically about people who are blind and sight-impaired and is the focus of the present article.

affiliation: 1 Works for The Evolvers Group, an EAI consulting company headquartered in Dallas, Texas. He studied Electrical Engineering at University College of Engineering (Burla) in India. His current interests include use of Internet-Intranet as productivity enhancement/marketing tool, sociocultural impact of CMC, the emerging convergence of media and technology companies on the Web and its impact on industry.
